Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2010 07:13AM Ezscriiibe wrote: Also, go to the Unjury website. I used their products last summer when I was on a completely liquid diet due to some severe gastro-intestinal issues, one of which turned out to be a horrible ulcer. (like there is any other kind) It's medical quality protein, and it's one of the best tasting I've ever used. In fact, I'm using some during my chemo treatments.  Here's a link that explains Unjury's Protein score: http://www.unjury.com/reg/nutrition.shtml Also, each serving has 20 grams of protein. I generally buy the sample sizes (they are individual servings) because it's easier for me to make smoothies, etc. (I try to start each day with the Strawberry smoothie -- ice cubes, splash of water, cut up banana, then blend with my Magic Bullet blender for 30 seconds or so).

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2010 05:39PM - edited Jan 11, 2010 05:41PM by Ezscriiibe Wow! I had no idea that I would connect with this many who may have been exposed to DES! Over the years since my initial bout with cancer, I have found no one, not ONE person, who has even HEARD of DES, much less may have been exposed to it! I usually have to go into the entire background about it. I know there is no way for any of us to be able to confirm that we would or would not have developed our various cancers had we not been exposed to this particular medication, but I was curious as to how many in this group might have been exposed. It's anecdotal information, for sure, but interesting to me nonetheless! PS: I apologize for not responding to your posts earlier, but there's apparently a restriction on posts a new person can make in any one 24-hour period. I was not aware of that or might have "spent" my post allotment more wisely!
Posts.Title: DES Expsoure and Increased Cancer Risk Ezscriiibe NativeMainer

Posts.Content: Ezscriiibe wrote: I'm in my early-mid-fifties and am the daughter of a woman who was prescribed DES during her pregnancies during the 1950s. I was just curious how many other women out there have also been exposed to DES during the years it was commonly prescribed to pregnant women. It's a sort of synthetic estrogen that was prescribed to pregnant women as a matter of course during the 1950s through the late 1960s or so. It was as common as prescribing folic acid or iron supplements today and the belief was that it reduced the risk of miscarriages. Even if the woman was not at risk for miscarriages (like my mother), they still were likely prescribed DES during their pregnancies. In the early 1970s the FDA discovered a link between DES and various reproductive abnormalities, not only in the women taking it, but to the unborn children they were carrying. Further studies have shown that even the granddaughters have a higher risk for various reproductive abnormalities. Here is what one site says about it: "More than 30 years of research have confirmed that health risks are associated with DES exposure. However, not all exposed persons will experience the following DES-related health problems. Women prescribed DES while pregnant are at a modestly increased risk for breast cancer. Women exposed to DES before birth (in the womb), known as DES Daughters, are at an increased risk for clear cell adenocarcinoma (CCA) of the vagina and cervix, reproductive tract structural differences, pregnancy complications, and infertility. Although DES Daughters appear to be at highest risk for clear cell cancer in their teens and early 20s, cases have been reported in DES Daughters in their 30s and 40s (Hatch, 1998)." I was diagnosed with both uterine and ovarian cancer in my late 20s. My sister, born about 18 months after me, has had horrible problems with breast cysts as well as fallopian tube problems all her life. She was lucky to have her one son. I was lucky to have my one daughter. My mother ended up giving birth to 6 children, 3 boys and 3 girls, but stopped taking the DES during pregnancy after my sister was born. My sister, me, and my older brother are the only three children who have exposure to the DES. We are the 3 oldest.  Speaking of my daughter, she, too, has had breast cysts and uterine abnormalities. She was diagnosed with CCA a year and a half ago just one year older than I was when I was diagnosed with my uterine cancer. She, fortunately, has 3 sons, so is not at all missing the organ! My mother was diagnosed with and treated for breast cancer about 3 years ago. She's doing fine. Now, her mother also had breast cancer, so there's something to be said for that. Still, though. I'm well aware of all the problems DES exposure presents and was curious how many women in this age range might have been exposed to DES in the womb as I and my sister were. Michele ~ mets to liver; biopsy revealed that the cancer has mutated from ER+/PR+ to ER/PR - Dx 1/7/2010, IDC, 2cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 0/1 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: DES Expsoure and Increased Cancer Risk Ezscriiibe NativeMainer

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2010 08:51PM Ezscriiibe wrote: You're welcome, Diana. I think I would have the same feeling about it as you, Diana, given your mom's history. DES was not given to my mom because she had any risk factors or previous miscarraiges. In fact, it was pretty much to all the pregnant women in her area as a matter of course. The women didn't need to be at any risk whatsoever for miscarriage. It was just something the doctors added to the list of various things they required of their OB patients.  And, unfortunately, many women during that time never ever questioned their doctors. My mother thought it was a vitamin type of thing and did not even have any idea what it was really for. But, that's not really why I started the thread. I was just curious, anecdotally, what the incidence of DES exposure might be for some of us. Thanks so much, everyone, for sharing your stories.
Posts.Title: DES Expsoure and Increased Cancer Risk Ezscriiibe NativeMainer

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2010 02:28PM - edited Apr 18, 2010 02:29PM by Ezscriiibe Oddly enough, my mom had a single mastectomy several years ago. She was small chested to begin with. She never wears bras or forms. In fact, she has pretty much even forgotten that she had a mastectomy! We were talking at lunch one day about whether I will get a mastectomy and, if so, double or single. I told her that I would definitely get a double, since it would be awkward to manage with one breast a 44D and the other. . . nothing. I then said that it would be a little different than hers, since she was much smaller. She looked at me quizzically and said, "I had a mastectomy?" Then  pulled her shirt out to look down and said with a laugh, "Oh yeah! I forgot!"

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2010 07:09PM Ezscriiibe wrote: Your sore throat and fatigue could be a result of your emotional fears. Or something else. When it comes to our breasts and suspicious "lumps," I don't think anyone should feel like they are worrying over "nothing." I think that sooner we can investigate and determine the cause for the lumps or our other symptoms, the better. If it is "nothing," then no harm, no foul. If it is the beginning of something, then the earlier you deal with it, the better. Who is your follow up with? Your Gyno or your GP?

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2010 12:31PM - edited Feb 10, 2010 12:32PM by Ezscriiibe Oh, hugs to you, sweet Judy! Sounds perfectly dreadful! Especially if you were not told of what to expect! My husband and I just finished up our Chemo Boot Camp today with my nurse navigator from the Cancer Resource center. We spent several hours with her going over each and ever possible side effect and a protocol to help deal with each one. I'm so surprised they didn't warn you about the hyperness with the steroids! Yikes! I also had to meet with my family doctor/endocrinologist because some of the medications (including the pre-chemo antibiotic I was given) create glucose issues for me, one shoots my glucose levels up (will need use a sliding scale insulin those days), and the other drops my glucose dangerously low (the antibiotic, of all things!). It was an exhausting morning, but I was very glad for such fine-tooth comb detail. My husband was, especially. Now he has something HE can work with to help me out! He's printed up all sorts of sheets with checklists for each side effect! What a goober he is sometimes! I figure, if I expect the absolute complete WORST, and don't get it, then BONUS to me!!

Fortunately, there are two surgeons in the same surgeons group who DO work only with breast issues, and it was one of those that I selected. Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2010 08:38PM Ezscriiibe wrote: Oh, Melissa, that's just not something you need to hear while going through this! How frustrating and upsetting! Please keep us posted on your breast surgeon experience. I have to admit, I was like you and did not know there was any difference. I asked my family doctor, after the needle core biopsy came back, what to do next. He is the one who said I needed to go see a breast surgeon. I suggested the surgeon that I used last year for a stomach issue and he said that he would prefer that I go to a breast surgeon as they are the ones who do this all the time. This is there "core" business (no pun intended) and he would just feel more comfortable with me seeing a breast surgeon. Without that sort of input or feedback, I would have just gone to my previous surgeon and thought nothing more of it either! I would also be stopping by the GS's office and picking up a copy of my pathology report if I were you, too. Even if I couldn't understand it, I would want it and not want to wait until he gets back from vacation! What is with that?! Does he not have another surgeon who can back him up for stuff like that? That's a long time to wait for such an important report!

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2010 08:24AM Ezscriiibe wrote: Sweet Aida, my heart goes out to you and your mom. I'm 53, and my daughter is 32. We are very close as well, and speak several times a day. She and her family come over to my house every weekend on Friday night and generally "hang out" until Sunday evening. We do so many things together and, aside from our respective spouses, are each other's best friend. I know the hardest part for me when I was diagnosed was telling my daughter.  I know you are scared and it's always rough to think of the very real possibility that our good friends and moms may not be there as long as we had always thought they would be. The key for everyone is knowledge. The more you know about this foe, the more control you have. It's that sense of loss of control that can easily spiral out of control.  Take back that control. My daughter became a breast cancer researching monster!  All my best to you and your  mom and I know you will both come out of this stronger and closer than ever before!

Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2010 08:01PM Ezscriiibe wrote: Deborah: Hugs for your hair fail! I know that I would feel the same way. It's possible that the colorist simply did not take into account the residual chemo chemicals that may be in your "new" hair and how they might interact with the chemicals in the hair coloring mixtures. I have heard that this can be a problem with people post-chemo. I know that the hair can retain all sorts of toxins as it grows, which is one reason they can check hair samples for things like exposure to arsenic or lead. I wish I had some constructive advice for you, but know that I'm feeling  your pain, as unhelpful as that might be!

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2010 03:10PM Ezscriiibe wrote: Well, first of all, I would not be getting the mastectomy recommendations from the surgeon. I would speak to a medical oncologist and discuss in great detail with the reports mean and what the prognosis is for the various options. My breast surgeon wanted to use a very conservative approach to my breast cancer. The trend today is for the lumpectomies and lymph node removals, then chemo or radiation or whatever else. The medical oncologist would be a good starting point because if the margins are not clear, you may well be looking at chemo regardless. But he can discuss the benefits or not of the mastectomy as well. Frankly, I would wonder what sort of background with breast cancer your surgeon has, considering he is so fickle regarding the two pathologists. That would concern me.  So at the very least, I would also look at another breast surgeon who has an extensive background with breast cancer, and, in fact, where breast cancer may well be all of his practice. The thing that both of you need is to feel that you have some control over what is happening. Even a little. It makes a world of difference.  Also, do you and your wife have copies of her pathology reports? If not, get them immediately. There are tons of resources on the web, and on this site, that can help you make sense of them. That way you will have a more concrete understanding of what is being said or recommended and why. Best of luck to you! You are her rock! Let her cry, though. Tears have a purpose, believe it or not, they actually draw out the hormones that make us sad and stressed. Let her sit down and have a good long, hard one, then gather up your weapons (your reports and second opinions) and hit this thing head on!

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2010 08:16AM - edited Feb 28, 2010 08:18AM by Ezscriiibe Rosemary349 said: "I've just read that not only tumeric but also black pepper is a breast cancer preventer." I am a skeptic by nature, so I am very leery about claims such as this. Especially since, many years ago I did some research and discovered that something called "pepperine" is one of the higher level carcinogens. I believe it was placed higher on the list than tobacco. Pepperine is created in the body through digesting, breaking down, pepper once it's ingested. Additionally, one commercial use for pepperine extracted from pepper is as an insecticide. Pepper is one of the oldest spices and is in more things than you realize, including many brands of vanilla ice cream. Do I believe ingesting pepper causes cancer? No, but it would also take a great deal of evidence to convince me that it has any cancer-protection properties.

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2010 09:51AM Ezscriiibe wrote: Juannelle, I have my hair colored with "highlights" and "lowlights" and use an "ash" blonde color for the highlights. So my hair has darker, lighter, and medium colors throughout. It more closely approximates the natural coloring most people have (we don't realize it, but our all of our hairs really aren't the same color). Plus, the highlights and lowlights give my hair more "texture" so that my very fine, very limp straight hair doesn't look so blah. Of course, all that will change once my loyal soldiers abandon me! I'm still only about 10 days out from my first chemo treatment, so . . . .

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2010 11:57PM Ezscriiibe wrote: I'm wondering, who on this planet is not aware of breast cancer by now? So, exactly what are the "awareness" programs supposed to do? They've set a pretty low bar if it's simply to let people know that women still get breast cancer. It would seem to me that a true 'awareness campaign' would include important things, like, oh, I dunno, there are over 32 different kinds of breast cancer. I did not know that before I was diagnosed. I was aware of breast cancer, but had no idea there was more than 1 type. I thought breast cancer was breast cancer was breast cancer. And that's just the tip of the iceberg. If people out there are like I was, and I contend they are, then these 'awareness' programs are a big fat fail.

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2010 06:48PM Ezscriiibe wrote: Texasrose, that SIL is atrocious! However, my own sister pretty much is the same. She is convinced that I'm "faking" my DX and just want attention. I can see why she would say that, however, classic case of "projection." She was caught in a fraud case with her former employer claiming nerve damage due to some chemicals she was supposed to have come into contact with. She had told the opposing team's attorney's that she only had one brother (she has 6) and no sisters (she has 2) and that her mother was dead and her father has been estranged for 20 years (neither is true). When they deposed my brother, she never clued him in to the scam and he spilled the beans about the rest of the kids and that both parents were alive and well and the family spends time with both several times a year. So when they deposed me, I told some truths about her previous diagnoses, she was diagnosed with borderline personality disorder and nacissistic personality disorder when she was 18.  Her attorney backed out and they dropped the case. Anyway, I'm still very much "alive" and hope to be for quite some time, but it does weigh on the back of my mind, like today when my grandsons and my daughter and I went on our annual U Pick Pumpkin outing. I choked up thinking this is something I may only have a few times left doing. How do you keep from letting those thoughts overwhelm you?!
Posts.Title: Why do I feel we are being overlooked cmhartley blondiex46

He already took some antibiotics for it (a Z Pack), but that didn't knock it out. Now HE wants to say it's sympathy SEs! I told him to just call and get another round of meds before I have to hurt him! (the constant coughing and moaning is getting a little old! Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2010 07:58PM Ezscriiibe wrote: thegodfight, my insurance covered mine as well, after a risk assessment by a genetic counselor. However, even though mine was negative, my sister was still recommended to get it, or else have my mom get it -- and if positive, my sister should, if negative there is no need. My daughter, on the other hand, will NOT need to get one since there is no way for her to have inherited the mutation if my test was negative. My sister, however, still has a 50/50 chance of it being positive, so, if my mom doesn't get it, she will need to. My mom's is being paid for by medicare, so that is the way we are going. Again, if mom's is negative for the mutation, my sister will not need the test; if my mom is positive, she will absolutely need the test.

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2010 01:37PM Ezscriiibe wrote: < snip> I would not have put this doctor on my team had I known that a PA was going to act as a gate-keeper between me and the doctor." Two thumbs up on both of those statements . . . The very first thing I would do would be to make my feelings known to the doctor. I'm sure that no doctor wants his/her patients to feel like they have to go through a "gatekeeper" to access him/her. My BS gave me his cel phone number, as did my rad oncologist. Both have stressed that call anytime I want, even if it's just to chat. They are there for me. I was, to put it mildly, pleasantly surprised! I find myself sitting here throughout the day trying to think up things just to test this out, but so far have not! What bums me out is I HAD my BS's cell phone number that night I freaked out about my surgery dressing coming off and FORGOT I HAD IT! DOH! I'm just so not used to my doctors being that accessible! I'm hoping my med oncologist does the same thing!
Posts.Title: I love my oncologist . . . and looking for a new one NatsFan NatsFan

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2010 07:51PM Ezscriiibe wrote: NatsFan: This is really very common in the health care industry. They aren't doing anything unusual, and, unfortunately, don't even realize that it's a problem. I have a professor who makes it a point to request the "new patient-extended" office visit every time she makes an appointment with her gyno. Of course the appointment clerk alerts her that her insurance company will only pay up to the non-new-patient rate, and she is okay with that. There is a medical code for everything, and who you see on which visit, and how long that visit is is all part of it. I did not even know the "code" existed, but have since started using it myself. I make sure when I book my appointments that I book them for the one where I am actually talking with the doctor and for a minimum period of time (whatever or however that office codes it). It's what I call an "end around."
Posts.Title: I love my oncologist . . . and looking for a new one NatsFan NatsFan

Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2010 06:26AM - edited Jun 9, 2010 06:28AM by Ezscriiibe I have no idea what you are asking. Depending on the location of the lump, it most certainly can not be there one month, then "show up" the next. The reality is that it was there for quite some time and under the right pressure or manipulation it is easier to notice. I checked my breasts every month in the shower for years. Sometimes I would do it twice a month. In early December 2009, I felt NO lump. On January 2, 2010, I felt one that ended up being over 2 centimeters in size. In January 2009, the lump did not show up on my mammogram. On January 4, 2010, (scheduled 2 days after I first felt the lump), it showed up pretty as you please. I'm sure many other women can share similar stories. So I'm not really sure what you are asking.

Posts.Content: Ezscriiibe wrote: My 4 month follow up PET scan showed liver mets. Tomorrow morning I'm going in for a liver biopsy. My onc says that is to confirm that it is the breast cancer.  He has gone ahead and set up a chemo schedule for me starting next week (12 weeks, every 2 weeks with Avastin, Gemzar, Navelbine) That's if it is confirmed the breast cancer -- if not, well, then what? That means a completely new cancer that is liver cancer, which means -- what exactly? Can I still buy ripe bananas? I was originally diagnosed with BC in the left breast on Jan 7 of this year. I had breast-conservation surgery and the one node removed. I then had chemo followed by radiation. Some lesions that showed up on my liver prior to chemo this past Feb-April ended up being cysts. So there was no warning. This new liver "object" is listed as: There is new hypermetabolic mass in the anterior aspect of the liver near the junction between the medial segment of left hepatic lobe and anterior right hepatic lobe. Maximum SUV is 10.0 g/mL and this is consistent with a metastitc lesion. Michele ~ mets to liver; biopsy revealed that the cancer has mutated from ER+/PR+ to ER/PR - Dx 1/7/2010, IDC, 2cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 0/1 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2010 03:04PM Ezscriiibe wrote: It's so hard to add to what everyone else has said already. I suppose the uterine/ovarian cancer was basically "hidden" from everyone else's view. Only I would know a part of me was "missing." I know you can rationalize that about the breast too, but given that it's much more visible in general, it just seems more public. I hope I can remain positive. I'm sure there will be times when I'll be quite a downer bi*ch, though.  But one thing I keep trying to remember is that more women die from heart disease than from breast cancer. Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2010 04:08PM Ezscriiibe wrote: This is very interesting. I just had a conversation with my husband last night that has left me a little disappointed. I was just diagnosed last Thursday with breast cancer, and found out on Tuesday what type of cancer it is, Infiltrating Duct Adenocarcinoma. I have since done some searches on this type of cancer and it has left me somewhat anxious and, to be honest, just barely this side of freaking out. I asked my husband if he had looked at any of the material and he said, "No and I don't think I want to, either." Well, this is my very best friend in the entire world. This is the person I rely on for all of my support and the person to whom I GIVE all of my support. I feel like I need him to know exactly what this beast is and what I'm going to be facing. It feels like an extra burden to me to be the only person in this effort who has the whole picture. He said, "This is your body and I'll be 100% behind and support whatever you decide." For the first time in my life, I have never felt so alone!

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2010 12:23AM Ezscriiibe wrote: Hi, rockermom, I know exactly where you're coming from. If I've already posted this in this thread, ignore me, but if I haven't here's my perspective. I'm not wanting both off because I fear a REoccurence in my healthy breast, I want them both off because I fear that there is already cancer there that has just not grown enough to be detected. This cancer in my left breast was probably growing for something like at least 5 to 8 years before it showed up on a mammogram this year (it did NOT show up on a mammogram 12 months ago), and before I noticed the lump on my own in the shower before I even got the mammogram. So my concern is that there is already one in my right (so-called "healthy" breast) but we just can't know it yet. Even with more close attention, what if it's in a location that isn't as easily felt like this one was? What if it's in a location that won't be picked up by mammos as easily as this one was? What if it's not "found" until it's much further along than this one was? THOSE are the thoughts that plague me. That one is already there and just lurking. . . waiting. . . until my guard is down then wham. . ..  But I also know your ambivalence, too. My doctor keeps saying that he just wants me to make the choice I'm comfortable with, but he also keeps leaning heavily on the lumpectomy with radiation only, and tends to down-talk the bi-lateral.  So I feel like my family will think I've wimped out. That I am over-reacting and that I'm killing a fly with a cannon rather than a flyswatter.  In the end, I really don't care what they think, and I already know that there is no way to be 100% sure of ANY decision. But one thing I do know, I've made extremely hard decisions in the past. Life and death decisions. I know that once I make my mind up about something and excute on that decision, there is no room for regret. It forever is the best decision I could have made given the information and mindset that I had at the time of the decision. Once I make up my mind, it is what it is.  Good luck with your decision. You have to trust your gut, your own instinct.
Posts.Title: I JUST WANT THEM OFF JudeMama Delilahbear

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2010 11:43PM - edited Feb 25, 2010 11:43PM by Ezscriiibe LindaHatch, I would be very skeptical of basing my perception on how bad a drug's side effects may be from postings on any internet forum. There is a huge population of women taking the drug. There are side effects, but many are either common, not common or rare. The people who experience little or no side effects do not typically go around to internet sites and share their lack of problems. On the other hand, those people who hit the wall with side effects will. So it's a very very very lopsided view of the reality of the experience.  I had read some pretty scary things on here regarding radiation. When I talked to my radiation oncologist about those problems, he acknowledged that he had seen a handful of cases in his many years of treatment. Some he had only seen once or twice. Yet in reading on these boards, one would get the impression that the scary side effect was the average or the norm. That was simply not the case.
Posts.Title: Arimidex LindaHatch Cowgirl13

Posts.Content: Oct 1, 2010 07:55PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 02:51AM by Ezscriiibe I'm less inclined to believe in a strong stress = cancer connection. Our bodies have evolved through much rougher environmental stress than we can even dream of today. I'm not saying it's nil, but I don't believe it's strong. On the other hand, I'm completely convinced in a very strong connection between inflammation and cancer. Many more people exist for years with low level untreated inflammation in their bodies, caused by a variety of things from what we eat to environmental factors.  For me I think the key is inflammation; and where stress may be a factor, I think it is to the point where it contributes to the inflammation.

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2010 01:56PM - edited Feb 6, 2010 05:15PM by Ezscriiibe Too cute! Nancy, I hear you on the doctors out of network seeing you in the hospital. Last summer, I was admitted to the emergency room of the hospital that is my "In-Network" hospital. My stomach was swollen and distended and I was in a lot of chest pain (I had "frozen" stomach syndrome, plus I was allergic to phenigren, which I had just a couple days before during a colonsocopy.) Anyway, I received a nearly $400 bill from a doctor that looked me over in the emergency room. I kept telling them to submit the bill to my insurance company. They already did, but it was rejected. Guess what? Out of the I-don't-know-how-many doctors in that hospital that ARE in my insurance network, this one doctor was NOT! Now I ask you, how the hell is someone supposed to KNOW that in an emergency situation, and why on earth would anyone even think to ASK, since the HOSPITAL IS in your network? Such a racket. Anyway, I ask every single doctor who comes into my room from now on who they are and whether they are in my network. If they don't know, I won't let them look at me until I find out. I even pre-screen the docs in the surgery theater before I go in now. Stinks.

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2010 12:21AM Ezscriiibe wrote: 1Cathi, I'd like to pass along what I know from my experience with medications like Gabapertin. It's the generic name for Neurontin, which I took for probably 5 years or more for the same thing. I have had neuropathy for years. Probably 10 or more. It was the result of some lower spine damage from an autoaccident. The reason why those medications also show use for epilepsy and bi-polar is because they work in a different way than pain meds do. Neuropathy affects nerve conduction. Medications like that directly address nerve conduction issues. They "calm" the "firings" which can result in the odd sensations, the pins and needles, "electric shocks."  In many cases the doctors will start you out at the lowest level to see if that is effective. If it doesn't work, it doesn't mean that the medication itself isn't working, it just means your dosage may need to be adjusted up. And the doctor should do that incrementally. My neuropathy was gradually progressive. Which meant that the dosage I was on needed to be adjust upwards from time to time. Sometimes when that happens people automatically think that they are building up a tolerance to the medication. But they are not. It just means that the neuropathy is progressing and requires a greater dosage. But because it works on nerve conduction, it does not really affect your mind, like some pain medications can.  I eventually started needing to reduce my dosage level and now I don't take any at all. I do get some periods of neuropathy back, but it's usually when I've been under a great deal of physical stress.
